Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Science Needs with Advanced Seafloor Sensor Engineering to Provide Early Warning of Geohazards: Visioning Workshop and Roadmap for the Future
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs request funding to support a workshop focused on understanding current seafloor and subseafloor sensing, and future needs for instrumenting the seafloor to provide real-time data and engineering needs for geohazards and early warning. They propose a two-day workshop is Seaside, Oregon. The proposed workshop will bring together leading science and engineering experts within the fields of marine geology and geophysics, oceanography, sensors, communications, visualization, computer science, robotics, geotechnical engineering, and marine geomatics from the academic, government, and private sectors to develop a robust plan for addressing seafloor sensor challenges. The final deliverables will include a final report and a paper for submission to the American Geophysical Union's EOS journal.

Specific topics to be addressed include engineering needs for geohazards and early warning, development of sensors to measure seafloor deformation and temperature and fluid flow with high resolution over a large area. Strategies for transmitting data from the sensors to land quickly and efficiently (including advanced in situ data processing and data compression algorithms) will also be considered as well as methods for powering the stations using energy derived from the environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A workshop was held in Gleneden Beach, Oregon on July 12-13, 2018 to develop a roadmap for the future of seafloor sensing. The workshop brought together 64 participants from 34 different organizations from academia, government, and industry. Represented disciplines included marine geology and geophysics, oceanography, sensor design, communications, visualization, computer science, underwater robotics, geotechnical engineering, and marine geomatics. A particular focus was on instrumenting the seafloor for investigating, modeling, detecting, and providing early warning of geohazards, such as earthquakes, submarine landslides, and tsunamis.

Despite the rapid advancement of sensors for land-based applications (e.g., GPS, solid state sensors, and optical sensors), developing and deploying seafloor sensors for geohazard detection remains challenging, due to the harsh nature of the deep-sea environment. Corrosion, biofouling, high pressure, low temperatures, and opacity are just a few of the challenges that plague seafloor sensing and sensor networks. The workshop sought to overcome these challenges through the collaborative efforts of the science and engineering communities engaged in the design, deployment, and scientific use of seafloor sensors and sensor networks. Participants worked collaboratively to sequentially address the following questions over the two-day workshop:

1)      What are the science needs for seafloor sensing?

2)      What can current state-of-the-art technologies deliver?

3)      What are the gaps between what currently exists and what is needed?

4)      How do we bridge the gaps?

Workshop brainstorming sessions led to specific recommendations for: a) improving the quality of seafloor sensor measurements, b) creating new sensors and deploying them as quickly as possible, c) improving the cost-effectiveness of seafloor sensors, and d) making the sensors environmentally benign (or, ideally, environmentally helpful).

In addition to technology-specific recommendations, an overarching conclusion from the workshop is that to further seafloor sensor capabilities as well as the science derived from seafloor sensor measurements, we need to build a diverse community encompassing seafloor sensor developers, scientific end-users within academia, private industry, and government, and policy makers. A number of actionable strategies were identified to achieve this goal. The conclusions and recommendations from the workshop have been summarized in a comprehensive project report, which has been published at ScholarsArchive@OSU: https://ir.library.oregonstate.edu/concern/technical_reports/dv140069q
